title: Old church in an ancient surrounding
text:
You must purchase your access to Ancient Agora to reach this building.

Only a few building are still standing on the premise of the Ancient Agora. This one is one of them and you can also step in to look at the walls that was restored in 1956.

It is a small, distinctive 11th century church among larger structure on the site. However, today, you get a better idea of the cachet of this historical building due to the restoration work.

There are many beautiful churches in Athens, we can’t stop at each of them. While we were on the Ancient Agora site, we opted to look inside and we were not disappointed.

We took the combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis. If you already have your ticket, skip the line.

title: Nice exterior details
text:
The Little Metropolis is the nickname of Church of Theotokos Gorgoepikoos and Ayios Eleytherios.

Very small with very nice detailed exterior sculpture and simple interior. I’m happy we stopped.

title: Old Royal Palace now Parliament
text:
Well, I saw the parliament but I guess not from the same angle as most did. The grounds in front of the parliament was fine with a nice fountain in the middle. Meaning that I miss the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and the guards.

This Old Royal Palace, because at one point there was a monarchy in Greece, vocation has changed over time; hospital, museum and now it is the Hellenic Parliament. It is a simple square building.

title: Within the walls of the Ancient Agora
text:
You must purchase your access to Ancient Agora to reach this building and we appreciated to visit the Stoa of Attalos the two-story building converted in a museum where statues and artifacts are presented.

It was built and named after King Attalos II of Pergamon, who ruled in the city between 159 BC and 138 BC.

Other buildings on the ground of the Ancient Agora includes the ruins of the gymnasium, the beautiful church of Holy Apostles, the Temple of Hephaistus, statues, all confirm the presence of a diversity of events that occurred on these grounds.

We took the combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis. If you already have your ticket, skip the line.

title: Greek dramatist - Athenian New Comedy
text:
To us visitors, we might not know who Menander was but logically next to the Theater of Dionysus we could have concluded that he played a role in this field and we would have been correct. Menander was a Greek dramatist and a recognized symbol of the Athenian New Comedy. While most of his work was lost during the Middle Age, only parts of very few of the 108 comedies he wrote was found and other authors and comedians referred to him and his work. The title and the importance of this public figure to Greek culture during his time and after are undeniable and thus, explaining the fact that he deserves a spot in the Acropolis site.

While on the Acropolis site you can see also the Theater of Dionysus, the Odeon of Herodes Atticus and on top of the Acropolis Hill, surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propylaea and the Erechtheion.

All this, for the price of 1 ticket. If you want tricks on how to skip the line see my review on the Acropolis.

title: Unique Bronze
text:
There was not much to do around the area in the afternoon so we decided to stop in this museum. While many artifacts are actually funeral monument or stone, sculptures, my favorite sections to visit the Zeas outdoor theater and the bronze statues room.

The bronze statues are an impressive exhibits, in very good form.
They close early at 3PM / 15h00. The 2 story building is easy to navigate and even if you only have an hour, go.

title: Green shaded paths with benches
text:
Between the Stadium and Zappeion, the National Gardens are not so inviting. Yes, we walked every day a certain path but we were not even interesting in seeing more. We may have miss something.

To me, National Gardens are a bit more attractive. Yes, it offers a green shade are, different paths and benches but that is it. The front of Zappeion (Zappeion Garden) is nice with the fountain and sculpture around the grounds.

But in the National Gardens, in August, a very high pitch insect sound did not make our journey in the area a relaxing one.

My review on National Gardens does not include Zappeion.

title: Don Juan autor - Lord Byron English romantic poet - Greek hero
text:
Not much information is indicated on the statue of Lord Byron in Athens. We only realized his importance to the Greece population when you read about his history.

Well, if I tell you the Story of Don Juan, does that help? Yes, Lord Byron the English romantic poet is also a Greek hero for political work during the Greek War of Independence.

The Statue sits there secretly from crowd that pass by. Unless you are with a tour guide you might not know who he was. It is very close to Hadrian's Arch and the Zappeion

title: Small and solid
text:
There are a few buildings/structures while atop of the Acropolis and this one is a little shy. Yes, because of its size and its location. Situated on the edge of the hill you are likely to be looking at your steps on your way up or down to access the gate and you may easily miss it.

On your way up once you cross the gate you will probably be naturally attracted to the Pantheon just in front of you. As you circle it, you may forget to turn around to see the Temple of Athena Nike.

When and if you take the time to look at it, it is clear that maintenance and conservation work has been done on the building. While it is small it looks solid with its beautiful golden white marble and four (4) columns on opposite sides of the temple, which all used to be a single piece stone columns. It says that at one point a wingless statue of Athena Nike was inside, symbol of victory in the hope that it will never leave the city.

While on Acropolis site you can see the Theater of Dionysus, Odeon of Herodes Atticus Theater and on the Acropolis Hill, surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propylaea and the Erechtheion.

All this, for the price of 1 ticket. If you want tricks on how to skip the line see my review on the Acropolis.

title: Sit and look. You will have a better perceptive: floors + bench + sculptures
text:
The Theater of Dionysus is part of the Acropolis Hill visit. While it sits at the foot of the hill, you are most than likely to see it on your way up when you are on the south side of the Acropolis. Don’t underestimate this place, it is said to be the first theater ever built and a great place for major artistic presentation event such as Greek comedy. Artists performed in front of as many as 19,000 people. S Unfortunately it does not look this impressive today.

You will see two important theater on your way to the Acropolis this one is the oldest and both are often mistaken. I went back to my photo to ensure I was taking about the correct one.

During my visit to Greece, I’ve seen many times the name Dionysus and I only understood on my return that Dionysus was actually the god of plays, wine, fertility and more. Thus the reason why he was honored on many occasions.

Part of this open air auditorium (it was reaching out even higher on the hill) have not survived the turbulent years however, do not just pass by. Sit on the stone bench, you can see a new perceptive and the hidden sculptures not visible when just passing by.

While on the Acropolis site you can see also the Odeon of Herodes Atticus Theater (closer to the Propylaea and the still active concert place) and on top of the Acropolis Hill, surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propylaea and the Erechtheion.

All this, for the price of 1 ticket. If you want tricks on how to skip the line see my review on the Acropolis.

title: Take a peek at the Atrium
text:
Zappeion is a beautiful yellow wide building in the National Garden sector near the Panathanaic Stadium. The choice of the location is not a mistake and was wisely designated for the proximity of the stadium in order to be used for the first modern Olympic Games. In fact, it seems to be the first building to be constructed specifically for the modern Olympic Games. While its vocation has changed over time and included political events, radio station, participate in different ways in a few Olympic Games (for press once, athletes at another time and fencing competition) it gives you an idea of the diversity and the potential of this building.

Today, its functions are mainly conference/Exhibits/meeting place where room as available to host public and private events.

We were allowed to just step in and see the atrium. Very nice.

The front area with the fountain is also pleasant.

title: Origin of the Olympics is Athens, is this place!
text:
This was our first stop to our visit in Athens and we were surprise by the quality of the structure and for a reason, it is actually one of the best preserve historic site. However, it is not as old as the other sites. While it was used back in 330BC it has been improved over time to welcome the 1896 first modern Olympic Games.
The less than 60,000 spectator marble horseshoe shape stadium is solid.

We understood that the decision of hosting the first Olympic games did come with an important challenge, funding. The city was, at the time, under financial difficulties and the construction of the stadium is undeniably associated with the financial contribution of prosperous entrepreneurs like George Averoff who made it possible and who’s statue is on the front of the site.

From there you can easily have access to the Zappeion,- National Garden, the Temple of Olympian Zeus, the Hadrian’s Arch and the National Garden.

title: Free photo stop
text:
I have to admit that I was disenchanted when I noticed the Arch. I’ve come to realize that regrettably the real story is vague and uncertain and no information is provided on site.

We have to admit that it can be difficult to find our genealogy so going back to this time is a challenge. It is normal that we may have lost track of some elements. All we know is it is associated to Emperor Hadrian but was it under his initiation or a gift from the Athenians.

The arch have resist many physical stress. It is easy accessible and no cost to get up close.

You are at a walking distance to many site including the Temple of Olympian Zeus right in the background. But besides that nothing else.

title: No added value - no learning experience
text:
If I remember correctly, Zeus being the king of the Olympian gods. This is the reason why they named this place Olympian Zeus.

It was under Emperor Hadrian that this ambitious project was finally completed after it took centuries to finish.

While I thought I was there to visit also Hadrian’s Arch, you actually do not need to get to the place to get close to the Arch. This site is the Temple of Olympian Zeus. Only a few columns have survived over the years. Some are laying down while some are still standing. You actually have a nice view of this site when you are atop of the Acropolis.

To me, not worth it on its own. However, this is where we purchased our combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Ancient Agora, Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library and Acropolis. No line up.

You are at a short walking distance to the Panathenaic Stadium.

title: Other reason to visit the Acropolis Site
text:
This is one of the two theater accessible on the slope of the Acropolis. This one is not the oldest but the one that has been renovated to welcome artists from around the world still today. The whole surrounding, the façade, the love story of Herodes Atticus, the city backstage and the Acropolis hill background makes this place way bigger than the 5,000 spectators capacity. No wonder why it is still active today and many musical performance have been held here. It provides a unique stage and show.

While on the Acropolis site you can see also the Theater of Dionysus and on top of the Acropolis Hill, surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propylaea and the Erechtheion.

All this, for the price of 1 ticket. If you want tricks on how to skip the line see my review on the Acropolis.

title: The Highlight of the Roman Agora
text:
The tower is a distinctive octagonal marble structure decorated of frescos on each facade and once you realize the function of the tower, you realize how clever it is. It is not only a clock tower it is actually considered the world's first meteorological station. It’s a combination of sundials, a water clock, and a wind vane used to stand atop.

The frescos represent the direction of the wind.

You can't visit this Tower only, This is part and my favorite part of the Roman Agora.

To access the Roman Agora, you can take a combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along with others: Ancient Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis. If this is in your plan.

I would suggest more and better information on site on this tower.

title: Introduction to an impressive site: the Acropolis
text:
In Greek architecture, the porch or the entrance to an important site is called a Propylaea.

The Propylaea to the Acropolis is a great architectural example of this imposing Greek gate that leads you the monuments.

The structure is light in color and imposing in size. We have to wonder how did built such a remarkable gate at the time that cars did not exist. The marble, the balanced, fix and very tall columns sitting just the edge of the hill. You will be impressed and realize its amplitude as you get closer. It is not easy to just stop and look in this section you kind a need to move with the crowd.

On your way up if you can look on your right to see the Temple of Athena Nike.

While on Acropolis site you can see the Theater of Dionysus, Odeon of Herodes Atticus Theater and on the Acropolis Hill, on site surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike and the Erechtheion.

title: A closer look at the details of the Acropolis
text:
You may wonder why or if you should visit the Acropolis Museum if you think about going or you went to the Acropolis Hill, well yes you should go. What happened is the Acropolis is very old structures and the reason why we are lucky it is still standing despite being expose to everyday wind, sun and climate is because of constant support and restoration. In order to preserve original masterpiece, they had to replace some original work on the top of the Acropolis with copies and they are keeping the original version at the museum.

In order words, the Acropolis Museum is an archaeological museum focusing on the Acropolis original artifacts. It allows you to have a closer look to the work of art.

Why doing both the museum and the hill, you get up close and the details at the museum and you get the surrounding context on top of the hill.

We followed other travelers’ recommendation and we visited the Acropolis Museum first and the next day we visited the actual Acropolis site. I think we all appreciated more the Acropolis Hill after seeing the museum. We had the time so we did.

From the entrance area, the clear floor allows you to see the exaction site underneath the museum.

Unfortunately, the museum combo pass do not work at this location. Line up can be long but it is totally worth it.

Watch out - around this neighborhood - pickpockets Grrrrr!

title: Sitting right next to the Panthenon - on Acropolis hill
text:
This is part of your Acropolis visit.

What I liked about this building is the fact that it is different. Typical ruins are supersize buildings with imposing columns with frieze. This one has a unique feature. On one side, as you are coming in the Propylaea and see the Acropolis, you also see a porch with larger-than-life draped ladies columns. This is the Erechtheion.

While we saw the original version of the ladies in the Acropolis Museum, seeing the actual location and the surrounding is something even better. It is a great idea to have created replicas since it gives the perceptive and stature when sitting right next to the Pantheon.

While on the Acropolis site you can see the Theater of Dionysus, Odeon of Herodes Atticus Theater and on the Acropolis Hill, on site surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propylaea and the Erechtheion.

All, for the price of 1 ticket. If you want tricks on how to skip the line see my review on the Acropolis.

title: Hidden - life-size statue of Nike
text:
Adjacent to the Roman Agora is Hadrian’s Library where you can find the ruins of the largest structure erected by Hadrian. While there is not much left on the site and it is very difficult to have enough imagination to realize the amplitude of the place, it is supposed to be more than a library, but also a place that held music and lecture rooms.

In a small room on the site of Hadrian Library, you can find one of the most interesting element: A life-size statue of a Nike (Victory) on a globe. But besides that… nothing more to see.

We took the combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Ancient Agora, Roman Agora, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis.

title: 2 reasons to visit: Jules Cesar and the Tower
text:
The Roman Agora was a delimited square surrounded by shops, storerooms and offices. The Gate of Athena Archegetis marked the entrance to the market/business/commercial/trading area. When compared to the other historical site, you kind of wonder why you should stop here.

Well, I can give you 2 reasons:
1. Jules Cesar
2. The tower

Yes, the Emperor Jules Cesar played a role here, he with Augustus financed part of the construction.

The tower is a distinctive octagonal marble structure decorated of frescoes on each facade and once you realize the function of the tower, you realize how clever it is. It is not only a clock tower it is actually considered the world's first meteorological station. It’s a combination of sundials, a water clock, and a wind vane used to stand atop.

The frescos represent the direction of the wind.

We took the combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Ancient Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis.

title: Place to walk and discover the old Athens
text:
The Ancient Agora is also a proof that Athens is one of the oldest city in the world. The buildings still standing and ruins around testify the active life there many many years ago.

A mix of purposes shows that this gathering place was lively. The ruins of the gymnasium, the beautiful church of Holy Apostles, the Temple of Hephaistus, the Stoa of Attalos (now a museum) confirm the presence of a diversity of events that occurred on these grounds.

We appreciated the Stoa of Attalos the two-story building converted in a museum where statues and artifacts are presented. Also, the church is also unique and the Temple of Hephaistus surprisingly still stands tall.

We took the combo ticket that allowed us to visit this site along others: Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus and Acropolis.

Enjoy your visit.

title: Can't miss it!
text:
The Parthenon sits proudly on top of the Acropolis Hill. The temple dedicated to the goddess Athena was completed in 438 BC.

It can be seen from many locations in the city.

Since it is part of the Acropolis visit, on site surrounding the Parthenon you can see the Temple of Athena Nike, the ruins of Propleia and the Erechtheion.

Today, luckily the basic structure still remains tall compared to other ruins in Athens. It gives a glimpse at the general overall size and imposing arrangement.

My suggestions for your visit:
1. Skip the line
Buy a multisite ticket at another attraction and pass the ticket booth.

You can go to one of the following less crowded attractions: Ancient Agora, Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus, Kerameikos, Aristotle’s School

So when you get to the Acropolis ticket booth you do not need to do the line-up! The difference in price was totally worth it to us.

2. Visit the Acropolis Museum first
Unfortunately you can’t skip the line at the museum but it is a good way to see the original version of the art with more details.

3. Allow sufficient time
Give yourself time to enjoy the Parthenon but the other buildings as well and also the view of the city below.

4. Pickpockets
Careful at the bottom of the Acropolis near the ticket booth yep! It happened to me – group of young girls.

5. Climb
I’m not so in shape and the climb was easy, so do it, try. On your way up, go at your rhythm and stop. Sometimes, you can be surprise of things you can see when you sit down and look around.

Don’t miss the Dionysus theatre.

title: Once it's done - it's done
text:
When we think about Athens we automatically think about the Acropolis and the Parthenon. The Acropolis is the dominant hill and the Parthenon among other historical buildings proudly stand on the top of a flat rock.

The Acropolis is more than the Pantheon, you can see the ruins of the Propylia, the temple of Athena Nika and the Erechtheion as well.

If you visit Athens, it is a most to visit this place at least once in your lifetime. It is the best historical site in terms of actual standing structure.

From the top, walk around and look down at the city. Beautiful views.

My suggestions:
1. Skip the line
Buy a multi-site ticket at another attraction and pass the ticket booth at the Acropolis.

You can go to one of the following less crowded attractions first: Ancient Agora, Roman Agora, Hadrian’s Library, Temple of Olympian Zeus, Kerameikos, Aristotle’s School

So when you get to the Acropolis ticket booth you do not need to do the line-up! To me, the difference in price was totally worth it.

2. Visit the Acropolis Museum first
Unfortunately you can’t skip the line at the museum but it is a good way to see the original version of the art with more information.

3. Allow sufficient time
Give yourself time to appreciate the location, the buildings and also the views at the city below.

4. Pickpockets
Careful at the bottom of the Acropolis near the ticket booth yep! It happened to me – group of young girls.

5. Climb
I’m not so in shape and the climb was easy, so do it, try. On your way up, go at your rhythm and stop. Sometimes, you can be surprise of things you can see when you sit down and look around. Wear good shoes- avoid flip flop and high heels.

Enjoy the most see attraction in Athens.

title: Whales - find them and appreciate the show
text: We took a tour with “Tadoussac Autrement” and we really appreciate it. Small 12 passenger covered heated boat is a good option in June. Even if the temperature is nice when you get in the open see… it can be chilly. Due to the boat size and the captain approach, it is easier to adapt the path according to what we can see. However, nature is nature and the show differs from day to day and hours to hours. We were lucky to see belugas playing and some rorquals for a while and then… nothing.

title: Admiring the outside was enough for us
text:
The Chauvin trading post is another stop and it reminds us the first economic reason of the region: the fur industry. The museum includes Amerindian artifacts as well as New France objects.

Accessible and easy walking access to the following attractions:
• Whale Watching (boat tour start)
• Marine Museum
• Oldest wooded chapel
• The Hotel
• The beach
• Jardin de la grève
• Pointe de l’Islet trail
• Lunch and Ice cream

title: Easy to add in your visit to Tadoussac
text:
Small cute historical accessible near to other attractions.
The small chapel is also name Indian Chapel or Chapel of Tadoussac or Eglise de la Mission de Sainte-Croix-de-Tadoussac.

Near:
• Whale Watching
• Marine Museum
• Trading post
• The Hotel
• The beach
• Jardin de la grève
• Pointe de l’Islet trail
• restaurants and Ice cream

title: knowledge staff
text: Small but informative on the habitat, the behavior and there is also a large skeleton. Do not hesitate to talk to the staff they will provide you unwritten information. Plus, if you can’t complete your visit, advise the person and keep your ticket, you might be able to re-enter to complete your tour but advise them.

title: Look and enjoy
text: Beautiful place. While it might take you 20 minutes to do the trail straight, you will more than likely stay for an 1hour just because it is nice. You are by the water and you might be lucky and see whales, belugas or seals. Good for lovers and family.

title: Beautiful inside and out - Art in many forms
text:
No wonder why so many pilgrims visit this place annually. You must stop by this place. It is a museum by itself that presents different art: architecture, sculpture, mosaic, copper, painting, deco and more.

We were all amazed by its beauty inside and out.

The entrance with the copper doors is something than the vestibule with mosaic all around representing different subject is just the beginning.

The interior with painted ceiling is not common, the stain glass is beautiful, the columns and the podium is of an incredible priceless beauty. It’s an amazing religious site and I have seen churches. My kids are tired of me stopping but this time, I think they noticed it and were they were as interested as me.

And don’t forget to visit the chapels on the lower floor - Beautiful again.
The grounds with the Ste-Anne fountain is also very pretty.

title: Missing some color!
text: While the church is located at the center of the village, like most did in the era, the main attraction of the village is really the artisans, artists and galleries. The structure looks solid, severe with straight lines and, to me, seems to be missing a bit of color/design especially in a neighborhood full of art.

title: Stroll by the water
text: At the end of rue St-Anne you get to a parking space. From there, you can find a sandy beach, playground, kayak rental, boardwalk, a dock and waking trail. Very quiet. We were there at sunset. Not much going on. Only a few people to take it easy at the end of the day.

title: Alternative route without being a long detour
text:
This is a nice alternative to the highway with cute area to stop. The culminate destinations being La Malbaie on one end and Baie St-Paul on the other. While most the time the scenic route is perceive as a long detour this is not the case here and it gives you another look of the region. We took the road on one way but not the other.

Note: both destinations are nice to visit.

title: New France residential building example
text:
This place can be listed in two categories. Yes a restaurant but also as a tourism attraction / historical building. Well this restaurant is actually the oldest residential building in Old Quebec City. It was built 1675-1676. You can find information on this building next to the door - Maison Jacquet.

This time, I stopped for the architecture not for food.

title: Tourism Information Center - for the City and more
text:
If we need help in finding what to see, what to do and what to not miss, it is a place to find useful information. It is an interesting way to get the best of your visit.

It is right across the Chateau Frontenac so easy to find and a good way to start your visit.

Note: The information they can provide exceeds the city area.

title: Surrounded by history
text:
Hotel de ville is French for City Hall. So you should not be surprise to learn that the Place de Hotel de Ville is right in front of the City Hall.

This square is nice to sit and enjoy the fountain/splash pad that kids love and see other historical building surrounding including the Notre Dame de Quebec Basilicl. You are also very close to the Muse de l’Amerique Francophone.

title: Art everywhere
text: Next to the Chateau Frontenac this narrow pedestrian street is full of artists. Colorful, joyful, plenty of talent.

title: Don't hesitate to us it if you need it
text:
There is a few ways to get from the Upper Town to the Lower Town and vice-versa, the funicular is one way but you can walk down the streets but it is not as nice using the famous Breakneck stairs - Don’t worry the name sounds worse than it is really!

By Funicular or via the stairs, at the lower section you reach the Petit-Champlain Area. The pedestrian only street is full of boutiques, restaurants and souvenir shops. On the Upper side you are next to the Frontenac Castle.

Picture opportunities and often busy, be ready to wait for the funicular.

title: Not a must see but if you are in the area...
text:
While trolling on the Plains of Abraham where you can see the equestrian monument this is where you can find the neat and simple Joan of Arc Garden.

Not that big but just nice.

title: Guided tours mandatory to visit the interior walls
text:
The Citadelle is an official residence for the Governor General of Canada and it is, as well, an active military installation for the Canadian Armed Forces – 22nd Regiment. If not in town city, it is possible to visit the Governor’s house. There is also a changing of a guard at 10AM but we missed it. Guided tours are offered - we opted out since we had limited time in the City and we were just beginning.

Unfortunately, but for obvious reasons, you can just walk around at your own pace. You must take part to a guided tour to visit the interior walls.

title: Charming Medieval look
text:
In the desire to limit access to the city, a wall with gates “doors” was built. The Porte St-Louis (St-Lewis Door) was one of the first three gates under the French regime. At one point, even under the British control, more gates were erected but with time and evolution, including transportation, most of them were demolished.

However, the Porte St-Louis was rebuilt to an improved version for today’s need. The previous style had narrow openings for pedestrian and carriage. With gates they were able to control access and prevent against potential invaders.

When at the Porte St-Louis you are at an easy walking distance of the Plains of Abraham, the Parliament building, the Citadel and the Chateau Frontenac. In fact, just follow the rue St-Louis (street) and you will get to the Chateau.

To my eyes, it has a medieval look.

title: THE oldest church in Canada
text:
Wow! This is the oldest church in Canada and the first to be designated as a minor basilica in 1874. Some governors of New France (including Frontenac) and bishops of Quebec are buried in the crypt.

No wonder why this church is a National Historic Site of Canada.

title: The name sounds worse than it is!
text:
Connecting the Upper Town to the Lower Town, it is one of the way to reach each section. The other way being the funicular and the streets.

It is nice to go down the stairs where you reach the Petit-Champlain Area. The pedestrian only street is full of boutiques, restaurants and souvenir shops.

Picture opportunities and often busy.

You get to the stairs via Cote de la Montagne.

title: Historical church on Place Royale
text: One of the oldest church in North America, this small religious church sits on the ruins of Champlain's first settlement. It fits perfectly in this neighborhood full of historical building and squares.

title: Quebec - key figures - heritage
text:
If you are at the Place Royale you are very close to this mural.

This fresco pays tribute to historic personage. I should have pay more attention. It is at the image of the neighbourhood, it fits perfectly in this area.

An historian can have a class in front of this mural to show younger generation and travelers the heritage of the Quebec culture in sports, music and key figures.

Very well done.

title: Where the water meats the old town - Improved area
text:
If you feel there are too many people, when I went by (no cruise ship), the old port was way quieter than the city. You can sit and enjoy the view, walk along the river, take a beer while soaking your feet in basins and relax. Since it is by the Petit-Champlain and the Place Royal, you can just decide after your break to continue your visit.

You can find at the Place des Canotiers in the Old Port where there is a fountain/splash pad that is refreshing and the kids love it.

Some sections have been updated, making this place nicer to walk around.

title: Free street art with a meaning
text:
While I’ve been to Petit-Champlain a long long time ago, one of the thing I remember is the Fresque du Petit-Champlain.

It gives us a glimpse at how it was like living in the area at the beginning of the New France. This mural is as tall as the building and it looks like the building is broken to present in a 3D realistic effect many details of life in the working neighborhood.

You can only get there on foot. If you get down the Breakneck Staircase, just continue on the street and you won’t miss it.

Other murals are in the old Quebec.

title: Historical battle field
text:
The plains is a wide nature area that groups a different elements both historical and actual. While it can be quiet at most times, big outdoor events are also held in this park.

Realizing that the day before was an important show on the park, the very next day we could barely tell.

While trolling on the plains, I appreciated the simple Joan of Arc Garden, the monuments and the National Battlefields Commission House. Also on the grounds, you can see the Tour Martello 2 and a museum as well.

If you park in this area, you have easy access to the different attractions.
- Citadelle de Quebec
Royal 22 Regiment Museum
Residence of the Governor General
- Musée national des beaux-arts du Quebec (Fine Arts Museum)
- Parliament building

title: Tribute to the city's growth!
text:
I'm impress by the imposing building where, statues are on and around the parliament which remind us of the presence of significant people who have marked the region.

At the foot of the central tower, two large sculptures pay tribute to the First Nations for their hospitality. Others are politicians or public figures who have been involved in the establishment of the city. Walk the grounds to appreciate the surroundings.

This place is also the origin of the expression: Je me souviens (I remember)

title: Beautiful historical site
text:
Located in the Lower Town this place was a major commercial centre in the early days, Place Royale has witnessed several major events dating back to the very beginning of colonization.

Today the bust of Louis XIV is presented in its center and is surrounded by historic buildings/ mansions and includes the beautiful Church of Notre Dame des Victoires. This is the oldest surviving stone church in North America.

title: The surroundings counts too!
text:
I don’t know why but I love fountains. Anywhere we go, if I see a fountain I have to get closer.

This one is no exception and not a disappointment. It sits just across the street from the parliament building for picture perfect opportunities. See the photo we took.

title: Simply lively!
text:
The delimitation of the old Quebec, the Haute-Ville and the other areas was not clear to me.

I had to do some research to understand something so obvious. Downtown Quebec City is divided into two parts, Upper Town and Lower Town which only depends on altitude. Lower Town is mainly the old port and the Petit-Champlain area – between the cap and the river. The Upper Town looks to me like a wider area that sits on top of Cap Diamand.

To me, you should visit both part to have a complete experience of the city.

You can walk the streets, walk up the stairs or take the funicular to reach the Upper Town when in the Lower Town.

Old Quebec is part of the Haute Ville, so is the Parliament Hill, the Plains of Abraham, many religious buildings, the Chateau Frontenac, the City Hall and many more historical buildings.

When I was walking in the Lower Town I felt relax and just happy to wander around and see what the next corner would bring me.

You can explore around for hours and I recommend on foot, it is the best way.
Many place to shop and eat in the area.

title: Wish I can go again soon!
text:
The delimitation of the old Quebec, the Haute-Ville and the other areas is not clear to me.

I had to google it to understand something so obvious. Downtown Quebec City is divided into two parts, Upper Town and Lower Town which only depends on altitude. Lower Town is mainly the old port and the Petit-Champlain area – between the cap and the river. The Upper Town is a wide area that sits on top of Cap Diamand.

Old Quebec is part of the Haute Ville (Upper Town), so is the Parliament Hill, the Plains of Abraham and many more historical buildings.

Many religious infrastructure are in the haute-ville. This is why you will find in this area a fewer religious buildings like: the cathedral, the Séminaire de Québec, the collège des Jésuites, the couvent des Ursulines, to name a few.

Forts and castle, like the famous Chateau Champlain (Castle) is in this area.

There is also many parks and square. Some parks in the Upper Town includes De l'Esplanade, Des Gouverneurs and Montmorency parks just to name a few.

The City Hall is also part of this neighbourhood.

You can explore around for hours and I recommend on foot, it is the best way.

title: Beautiful European influence area
text:
When you are in the Petit Champlain, you are in old Quebec – UNESCO World Heritage Site. You can only walk into this section of the city. You will pass by old buildings, houses on narrow streets, sometimes paved with stones, which reminds us of the European influence.

This area offers boutiques, restaurants, look around for murals and enjoy. You can have access to the Chateau Frontenac and the upper area via the funicular if you want to explore more than the Petit Champlain.

Very nice area.

title: On Foot - it is the only way!
text:
The capital of the province is so much more than just the Parliament. It is undoubtedly one of the most beautiful cities in the province. You have a lot to see and the best way to discover it is on foot.

The city shows an amazing historical and heritage richness with its century-old houses and sites. The only fortified city in Canada, you can visit many places, squares, art, ... Its narrow streets, sometimes paved with stones, reminds us of the European style and gives a romantic touch to the city where it is good to be day and night.

Did you know that the old Quebec is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Overlooking the river, the difficulty is to know where it starts and where it ends. There is so many squares, quaint streets that you may wonder around and no longer be in the old Quebec but even if this happen… as long as you appreciate where you are it is what it counts.

Be sure to see take the Breakneck Staircase, Quartier du Petit-Champlain, the murals, squares. This area offers boutiques, restaurants, look around and enjoy. You can have access to this area via the funicular next to the Chateau Frontenac.

title: Easy access - simple outing - nature force
text:
Very close to Quebec City, you can easily explore and discover the natural beauty of the Montmorency Fall.
The falls are actually 83 meters high, which is higher than Niagara Falls (51 meters).
First the access: You can park at the bottom or top section of the park. Your parking ticket is good for both if used the same day. The cost of access is limited to that of parking.
Don’t be surprise, the parking is the same for the park and for the Manoir (Manor) Montmorency.
At the top:
- The manor is a beautiful building recalling part of the history of the place.
o Restaurant on site
o Boutique
o Bathrooms
- Park green section with picnic tables
- Access to the falls via the suspended footbridge overlooking the falls
The cable car connects the base and the upper section. It is also possible to use the stairs. At the feet of the falls, you can get splashed from the fall, nice free refreshing option.
If you want to add other activities on site you can do zip-lining and/or rock climbing the walls of the falls, for additional cost of course.
At the bottom of the falls, you have a pretty even sidewalk to get close to the falls. A snack bar and a child park is also accessible when parking at the lower section.
Natural beauty, the whole family greatly enjoyed the visit.

title: 1865 Historical religious building
text:
It does not look like much today from the outside but this church have seen a lot. Built in 1865, it is one of the oldest religious buildings in Montreal.

According to Wikipedia: The Gesù witnessed the first "electric candle " lit in Canada in 1878.



It used to be Collège Sainte-Marie chapel where the Society of Jesus would support education. The church of Gesù is actually the only portion of the College still standing today. The walls of the college remains and a commemoration of the Society of Jesus are just outside the church.



The site is considered - Historic sites and monuments board of Canada.

You are close to the Place des Arts.

title: You do not see such a collection of locomotive too often.
text:
What an amazing day. Exceeded our expectation.

Do take the guided visit. It is 1:30tour but so worth it. Only once a day in French and once in English and not at the same time.

Historical wagons, passionate workers. Tramways, trains, cars,

This was not part of our original Sunday plan but decided to visit the Canadian railway museum on the south shore of Montreal in Saint-Constant.

They have so many train cars/locomotives on display, including the first ever in Canada, the private car of Sir John A. McDonald, first class private car that the Montreal Canadiens hockey team would travel in, absolutely huge steam engines of all kinds, Montreal tram cars, etc. They have an old original Montreal tram car running on site. But if there is too long of a line up you can walk easily to the end of the site. There's even a Montréal metro car there now.

We took the guided tour of the Angus hangar. We ended up being the only ones on the tour so we had a 90 minutes private tour to ourselves. The guide was great and he unlocked and brought us into an exclusive car to see The inside of the second class sleeper car was really interesting.

They have been collecting locomotive since 1962. So they have experience and now what a collection.
Retired operators are also volunteering and provides information.

Miniature train display, telegraph Morse code expert was also on site. It was just an awesome day.

title: Quiet August days - no one
text:
On one of our day trip down to Scott Head we stopped in different places which included Bubble beach spa. I have to admit, that I noticed the church first and we decided walk around and this is how I saw Bubble Beach Spa. It is a small beach and the site was closed. So I only touched the warm water and walked away but it looks neat and nice.

There is a photo bench by the water.

The journey was nice including this place I wish it would have been open.

Peaceful area of Dominica.

title: Picnic tables - Restaurant - rental equipment on this beach
text:
North of Portsmouth, you find at almost the end of the road Toucari Beach where you can snorkel, kayak, have a picnic (picnic tables on site) or enjoy the restaurant on site. This restaurant offers the renting equipment to enjoy the site. Keeping it real gives a nice relaxing, inviting atmosphere to this beach.

While the snorkeling was not at its best, the restaurant was very nice.
Did you know that there is the bubble effect at this beach also?
